content: The "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" aims to promote the construction and operation of US flag cruise vessels in the country. It includes an amendment regarding coastwise transportation of passengers. The "United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994" promotes US flag cruise vessel construction and operation. It includes an amendment stating that vessels in coastwise trade must be owned by a US citizen or entity, meet specific requirements, and be at least 5 net tons. The Shipping Act, 1916 and Merchant Marine Act, 1920 outline requirements for vessels in coastwise trade, including ownership by a US citizen, meeting specific criteria, and having a certificate of documentation. An exception is made for cruise vessels under a demise charter lasting at least 18 months. A cruise vessel under a demise charter lasting at least 18 months can operate in coastwise trade for up to 6 months after the charter ends with approval from the Secretary. A cruise vessel under a demise charter lasting at least 18 months can operate in coastwise trade for up to 6 months after the charter ends with approval from the Secretary, subject to certain conditions. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 exempts certain cruise vessels from specific regulations if they meet age and documentation criteria. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 exempts cruise vessels aged 5 to 15 years old from regulations if the owner has a contract for a new vessel with 80% capacity. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 exempts vessels with at least 80% capacity from regulations, with a termination clause if a new vessel is not under construction within 18 months of certification. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows for an 18-month period for a new vessel to be under construction before termination, with a possible 6-month extension for good cause shown. Operations of cruise vessels in coastwise trade are limited under the Act. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows for an 18-month construction period for new vessels, with a possible 6-month extension for good cause shown. Operations of cruise vessels in coastwise trade are limited, with restrictions on operating between certain ports and islands. Penalties are imposed for violations of these limitations. The Secretary issues coastwise endorsement; penalties for violating restrictions include a $1,000 civil penalty per passenger, vessel seizure, and disqualification from coastwise trade. The construction contract for a cruise vessel may lead to disqualification from coastwise trade if construction milestones are not met within a specified period. The construction contract for a cruise vessel may result in disqualification from coastwise trade if construction milestones are not achieved within a specified period. The term 'coastwise trade' includes passenger transportation within the United States, directly or via a foreign port. A 'cruise vessel' is defined as a vessel of at least 10,000 gross tons with accommodations for passengers. The term 'cruise vessel' is defined as a vessel of at least 10,000 gross tons with accommodations for at least 200 passengers, excluding ferries. A 'related person' includes holding companies, subsidiaries, affiliates, officers, directors, and agents of a person or entity. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS. Section 3309 of title 46, United States Code, is amended to allow vessels meeting specific standards to comply with certain subtitle regulations. The Secretary will issue a certificate of inspection to these vessels, which must meet criteria for control verification certificates and have a coastwise endorsement. The United States Cruise Vessel Development Act of 1994 allows for the issuance of a control verification certificate to a foreign vessel embarking passengers in the United States, provided it has a coastwise endorsement and authorization for coastwise trade. The Act of June 19, 1886 abolished certain fees for official services to American vessels and amended laws related to shipping commissioners, seamen, and vessel owners. SEC. 5. CITIZENSHIP FOR PURPOSES OF DOCUMENTATION. Section 2 of the Shipping Act, 1916 is amended to clarify citizenship requirements for vessels primarily transporting passengers in coastwise trade. Ownership by citizens of the United States is necessary for determining citizenship under this subsection. Ownership by citizens of the United States is required for vessels primarily transporting passengers in coastwise trade. The controlling interest in a partnership or association owning the vessel must be majority owned by U.S. citizens without any trust or fiduciary obligations to non-U.S. citizens. AMENDMENT TO TITLE XI OF THE MERCHANT MARINE ACT, 1936: Section 1101(b) is amended to include "passenger, cargo" instead of just "passenger cargo". Additionally, permits are required for vessels entering units of the National Park System. The Secretary of the Interior has priority in permitting vessel operations in the National Park System based on vessel documentation and rights to provide visitor services. The Secretary of the Interior prioritizes vessel operations in the National Park System based on vessel documentation and visitor service rights. Permits for foreign-documented vessels may be revoked. The Secretary of the Interior may revoke permits for foreign-documented vessels in the National Park System if a person requests permission to operate a US-documented vessel in the same unit. The Secretary of the Interior may not revoke permission for operating a US-documented vessel in a National Park unit due to permit limits. Additionally, permits cannot be revoked for individuals providing visitor services under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act. Any person holding rights to provide visitor services under the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act will have the right of first refusal for a permit if their permission is revoked. The number of permits available will be limited to those that are revoked or not renewed.
